What do the intercepts tell us about the problem?
The x-intercept tells us:
A) the cost of the TV ads.
B) the best number of TV ads.
C) the most TV ads she can buy for the money.
D) the average number of TV ads.
The y-intercept tells us:
A) the cost of the radio ads.
B) the number of radio ads she bought
C) the number of radio ads if no TV ads are bought.
D) the average cost per ad.
We find the x-intercept by setting y=0 and solving for x to learn that x=20\text{,} so the x-intercept is {\left(20,0\right)}\text{.}
We find the y-intercept by setting x=0 and solving for y to learn that y=60\text{,} so the y-intercept is {\left(0,60\right)}\text{.}
The x-intercept has y=0\text{,} that is, it corresponds to when there are zero radio ads. The y-intercept has x=0\text{,} that is, it corresponds to when there are zero tv ads.

statement.p: What was the most difficult part of this section to understand? Write a question whose answer would help you understand it.

li.p:
As part of a project to improve the success rate of freshmen, the counseling department studied the grades earned by a group of students in English and algebra. Do you think that a students grade in algebra is a function of his or her grade in English?
?
Yes
No
Explain why or why not.
A) Each value of x has exactly one value of y associated with it.
B) Two students with the same grade English can have different grades in algebra.
C) Two students with the same grade math will also have the same grade in English.
D) Two students with the same grade math can have different grades in English.

Phatburger features a soda bar, where you can serve your own soft drinks in any size. Do you think that the number of calories in a serving of Zap Kola is a function of the number of fluid ounces?
?
Yes
No
Explain why or why not.
A) The number of calories is proportional to the number of fluid ounces.
B) Two servings with the same calories will have different fluid ounces.
C) Two servings with the same flid ounces will have different calories.
No, students with the same grade in English can have different grades in algebra.
Yes, the number of calories is proportional to the number of fluid ounces.

statement.p: What distinguishes a function from other variable relationships?

li.p: A) The variables are related by a formula.
B) The values of the input and output variables must be different.
C) There cannot be two output values for a single input value.
D) There cannot be two input values for a single output value.

solution.p: There cannot be two output values for a single input value.

statement.p:
Is y a function of x\text{?}
?
Yes
No

li.p: Each value of x has exactly one value of y associated with it.
For example, x=3.5 corresponds both to y=2.5 and also to y=4.0

statement.p:
Is y a function of x\text{?}
?
Yes
No

li.p: Each value of x has exactly one value of y associated with it.
For example, y=3 corresponds both to x=-2 and also to x=2
No, for example, x=3.5 corresponds both to y=2.5 and also to y=4\text{.}
Yes, each value of x has exactly one value of y associated with it.

statement.p: How would you know if a table of values does not come from a function?

li.p: A) The output values are all the same.
B) The input values are not evely spaced.
C) Two different input values have the same output value.
D) Two different output values have the same input value.

solution.p: Two different output values have the same input value.

[_]{$input}{5}
a. What is the elevation at mile 20?

END_PGML

a. Approximately where [` d\approx 5 \text{,}`] [` d\approx 11 \text{,}`] [` d\approx 12 \text{,}`] [` d\approx 16 \text{,}`] [` d\approx 17.5 \text{,}`] and [` d\approx 18 `]

a. Approximately 165 feet
END_PGML_SOLUTION

water

solution.p: gasoline: \dfrac{67.5}{12}= 5.625 pounds per gallon, water: \dfrac{41.6}{5}=8.32 pounds per gallon. Water weighs more per gallon.

statement.p: The square base is 55 meters on each side, and the top platform is 19.5 meters on each side. Calculate the slope of the sides of the pyramid. Which pyramid is steeper, Kukulcan or the Great Pyramid (whose slope, rounded to two decimals, is 1.28)?

Answer:
?
Kukulcan
Great Pyramid

hint.p: The horizontal change \Delta x is half the difference between the sides of the base and of the top platform.

solution.p: The horizontal change \Delta x is half the difference between the sides of the base and of the top platform: \Delta x=\frac{1}{2}(55-19.5)= 17.75\text{,} so the slope is m=\dfrac{\Delta y}{\Delta x}= \dfrac{24}{17.75} \approx {1.35211}\text{,} which is greater than 1.28. Kukulcan is steeper.

m is

B) The burglary rate declined by 3.59 burglaries per 1000 households every year
C) The burglary rate declined by 3.59 burglaries per year
(in the years 1991 to 2001).

li.p: Because t=0 corresponds to 1990, we have the two points (1,64.6) and (11,28.7) to compute the slope m=-3.59\text{.} Using the point-slope formula with either point and then simplifying, we find that y = {68.19-3.59t}
-3.59 burglaries per 1000 households per year. From 1991 to 2001, the burglary rate declined by 3.59 burglaries per 1000 households every year.

statement.p: When does a table represent direct variation?

li.p: If it has a constant slope
If it includes the point (0,0)
If the ratio output/input is constant
If each output is double the previous one

solution.p: A table can represent direct variation if the ratio output/input is constant

statement.p: Which of the graphs above could represent direct variation? Explain why.

li.p: (a) The graph is a straight line that increases.
(b) The graph is a straight line through the origin.
(c) The graph is a straight line that decreases.
None of the above

solution.p: (b): The graph is a straight line through the origin.

statement.p: If \(y\) varies directly with \(x\), what does the constant of variation tell us?

li.p: The y-intercept of the graph
The slope of the graph
What happens to y when you double x
The size of the input values

solution.p: If \(y\) varies directly with \(x\), the constant of variation is the slope of the graph

statement.p: What does the scaling property of direct variation mean?

li.p: The output is found by scaling the input.
The output can be regarded as a scale.
The constant of variation can be multiplied by any factor.
If we multiply the input by p, the output will also be multiplied by p.

solution.p: If we multiply the input by p\text{,} the output will also be multiplied by p\text{.}

statement.p:

x 2 3 4 6 8 9

solution.p: (a): If we multiply x by c\text{,} y is also multiplied by c\text{.}

statement.p: Is the function f(x)=0.3x+5 an example of direct variation?

li.p: (A) Yes, it is linear.
(B) Yes, the scale factor is 0.3.

(D) No, its slope is less than 1.

solution.p: No, the graph does not pass through the origin.

solution.p: V=kr^3\text{,} and solving for k we find that k=\dfrac{4}{3}\pi\text{,} so V=\dfrac{4}{3}\pi r^3

statement.p: Find the coefficient of the fourth-degree term of the product of f(x) = 2x^6 + 2x^4 - x^3 + 5x^2 + 1 and g(x) = x^5 - 3x^4 + 2x^3 + x^2 - 4x - 2\text{.}
Answer:

solution.p: 2 is the coefficient of the x^4 term in the product.
To compute the fourth-degree term in the product, we multiply a term of f(x) of degree 4, 3, 2, or 0 by a term of g(x) of degree 0, 1, 2, or 4 respectively. We add those four products of terms:
So the fourth-degree term in the product is 2x^4\text{,} and the coefficient is 2\text{.}

statement.p: Explain how you know immediately that the following system is dependent:

A manufacturer of office supplies makes three types of file cabinet: two-drawer, four-drawer, and horizontal. The manufacturing process is divided into three phases: assembly, painting, and finishing.
A two-drawer cabinet requires 3 hours to assemble, 1 hour to paint, and 1 hour to finish.
The four-drawer model takes 5 hours to assemble, 90 minutes to paint, and 2 hours to finish.
The horizontal cabinet takes 4 hours to assemble, 1 hour to paint, and 3 hours to finish.

The manufacturer employs enough workers for 500 hours of assembly time, 150 hours of painting, and 230 hours of finishing per week. How many of each type of file cabinet should he make in order to use all the hours available?
Represent the number of each model of file cabinet by a different variable.
Number of two-drawer cabinets: x
Number of four-drawer cabinets: y
Number of horizontal cabinets: z
Organize the information into a table. (Convert all times to hours.)
\displaystyle{} 2-Drawer 4-Drawer Horizontal Total available
Assembly
Painting
Finishing
Write three equations describing the time constraints in each of the three manufacturing phases. For example, the assembly phase requires 3x hours for the two-drawer cabinets, 5y hours for the four-drawer cabinets, and 4z hours for the horizontal cabinets, and the sum of these times should be the time available, 500 hours.
Assembly time:
(1)
Painting time:
(2)
Finishing time:
(3)
Solve the system. Follow the steps suggested below.
Clear the fractions from the second equation.
(2)
Subtract Equation (1) from 3 times Equation (3) to obtain a new Equation (4).
(4)
Subtract Equation (2) from twice Equation (3) to obtain a new Equation (5).
(5)
Equations (4) and (5) form a 2\times 2 system in y and z\text{.} Subtract Equation (5) from Equation (4) to obtain a new Equation (6).
(6)
Form a triangular system with Equations (3), (4), and (6). Use back-substitution to complete the solution.
Enter the solution as an ordered triple.
You should have found the following solution: The manufacturer should make 60 two-drawer cabinets, 40 four-drawer cabinets, and 30 horizontal cabinets.

solution.p: Clear the fractions from the second equation.
{2x+3y+2z = 300} \quad (2)\text{;} then:
x = 60\text{,} y = 40\text{,} z = 30\text{,} so the solution is (60,40,30)\text{.}

For example, the assembly phase requires [`3x`] hours for the two-drawer cabinets, [`5y`] hours for the four-drawer cabinets, and [`4z`] hours for the horizontal cabinets, and the sum of these times should be the time available, [`500`] hours.
[@DataTable( [ [PGML('Assembly time:'), PGML('[_]{$eq1}{13}'), PGML('[`(1)`]'), ], [PGML('Painting time:'), PGML('[_]{$eq2}{13}'), PGML('[`(2)`]'), ], [PGML('Finishing time:'), PGML('[_]{$eq3}{13}'), PGML('[`(3)`]'), ], ], align => '*{3}{l}', valign => 'middle', );@]*
1. Solve the system. Follow the steps suggested below. i. Clear the fractions from the second equation.
[_]{$eq2a}{13} (2)
